column4: i was a sys admin for 14 years on a main frame Unix system.  I simply asked why.  There is not a unix system out there that doesnt have a root passwd
so I was simply trying to understand your reasoning behind what you were saying
My Ubuntu came with a root passwd already setup - That means somebody knows it - So I simply reset it.  No security risk...
Now, I am the only one that knows it
it could be random
how did you determine a passwd was already set?
my ubunto came from OSDisc.com on a CDrom - just stick it in and it loads up.
I looked in the /etc shadow file
it looked to have about an 80 character encryption
hmm odd, you can compare with the md5sums from the ubuntu release site to see if the iamge you have has been modified
thx -- it seems there are some differences on my box compared to what you guys talk about
I asked the other night if anyone loaded ubunto from the disk I did.  No takers, and OSDisc.com isn' returning emails,
maybe try a cdimage from another ubuntu mirror and verify the image matches the released md5sums then?
Sorry if I upset ne1
I'm new to Ubuntu.  I'm happy to have it up and running.
thx for the info
yw
using sudo>
i meant Akpsp
i use sudo alot.  Only after crashes and going into maintenance do I issue root and then run fsck
old habits are hard to break
